Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Regional Influence on Social Network Development

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Jacob Lulewicz from the University of Georgia will study how processes of societal transformation, including the emergence of sociopolitical hierarchies and socioeconomic inequalities, are shaped by the scale and structure of social networks. Previous scholarship on the development of organizationally complex institutions has focused on defining changes from one type of sociopolitical strategy to another through the identification of particular organizational traits at particular moments in time. However, these critical transformations are inherently embedded in broader historical and relational contexts, and are enacted through new and existing social, political, and economic networks. Archaeology is well suited to elucidating the relationships between social networks and societal change by focusing on the deep historical roots of institutions and capturing the historical and geographic nuances of sociopolitical development. Social networks contextualize societal change by both constraining and providing the means through which information is spread, social movements are facilitated, and ideas and innovations are adopted or rejected. The research will be conducted in the Southern Appalachian region of the Southeastern United States, where at ca. A.D. 1000, political leadership became centralized, large-scale political economies were formed through the mass intensification of agricultural production, social and economic inequalities became engrained, and participation in pan-regional ritual institutions proliferated.

Social networks at two complementary scales of analysis will be examined: 1) local networks, based on informal and frequent interactions, and 2) panregional networks, based on political affiliation and participation in religious and other cross-cutting institutions. Each network will be interrogated to better understand how they structured the emergence of new organizational strategies. Specific focus will be on the areas of modern day northwestern Georgia and eastern Tennessee where the characteristics and temporality of sociopolitical change followed distinct developmental trajectories. The researchers will construct network histories of Southern Appalachia to compare the differing sociopolitical trajectories of the northwestern Georgia and eastern Tennessee regions. The scale, structure, and tempo of changes to social networks across Southern Appalachia will be elucidated through (a) the construction of a regionally-integrated Bayesian radiocarbon dating program, (b) the construction of a regional database of stylistic and technological ceramic attributes, and (c) the assessment of regional patterning of politico-religious iconography through the analysis of shell gorget motifs and mortuary practices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to investigate how regional social networks structure transformations of social, political, and economic institutions. To do so, a large regional, archaeological dataset was assembled from Southern Appalachia, AD 600-1600. This period captures a number of major developments in sociopolitical organization including the emergence of centralized leadership positions, the development of large-scale political economies underwritten by intensified agricultural production, the establishment of institutionalized socioeconomic inequality, the residential aggregation of diverse populations at large regional centers, and the adoption of widespread religious practices. These changes would have put pressure on the social relations that underwrote the organization of Southern Appalachian societies and would have introduced significant levels of social, political, and economic uncertainty. How these societies collectively responded and adapted to such uncertainty was the primary focus of this project. The main goals of the project were to 1) identify and characterize major changes to sociopolitical institutions between AD 600 and 1600 across Southern Appalachia; 2) define the structures of social networks that constituted Southern Appalachian societies between AD 600 and 1600; and 3) evaluate how different kinds of social networks were transformed in the context of sociopolitical uncertainty and significant institutional change.

 

An updated timeframe for the region was developed that employed ceramic seriations and the acquisition of 70 new AMS radiocarbon dates funded by this grant. As social networks and institutions constitute major forms of social capital in both modern and past societies, they thus provide the means by which societies collectively respond to change, maintain durable organizational structures, and continue to persist and regenerate in the face of social uncertainties. Using a compiled database of over 350,000 ceramic artifacts, along with data on burial practices, monumental constructions, community organization, and religious participation, the durability and flexibility of social networks and sociopolitical institutions were evaluated in the context of long-term developmental histories. 

 

Two major periods of change could be discerned, one at roughly AD 1150 and one at roughly AD 1325. It is argued that these two points represent periods within which pressures on social organizations would have been heightened in the context of major social change and thus likely represent periods of heightened sociopolitical uncertainty. While changes to sociopolitical and economic institutions swept across Southern Appalachia at these times, they do not seem to have been concomitant with changes to the underlying social organizations of Southern Appalachian societies. That is, while these societies were undergoing major changes, the social networks that formed these societies were durable in the face of sociopolitical transformations. As such, it would seem that these changes, including the introduction of new leadership strategies, new forms of community and community organization, and altered economic and religious practices, were mediated and negotiated through historically durable social networks.  


A number of important insights for archaeological and anthropological research can be outlined. First, it is clear that an analytical separation between sociopolitical institutions and the social networks that underlie sociopolitical organizations is a productive distinction. In the case studied here, social networks did not change in concert with changes to sociopolitical institutions as would be expected in many traditional models of political development. Indeed, many of the extant approaches to the issues studied here focus on the material indicators for changes to sociopolitical practices from which changes to social networks and social organizations are then assumed to follow. Here however, it has been shown that these networks are actually the means through which societies are able to adapt and respond to sociopolitical uncertainty. In some cases, these networks may be durable, unaffected by major sociopolitical transformation. In other cases, these structures may need to exhibit flexibility in contexts of, as they may need to rearticulate with major changes to social, political, and economic organizations.

 

The project undertaken here has been framed in reference to a broader body of literature from across the social sciences related to social networks, collective action, and social change. This body of literature has been built primarily in the fields of political science, economics, and sociology. The first contribution to this body of scholarship is the time depth offered by this study. The majority of studies that have been used to build theory on collective action and social networks have been constrained by shallow time depths. This study provides a 1,000 year span of time that captures periods of both stability and change and is able to assess conditions before, during, and after periods of sociopolitical uncertainty. As such, this study contributes a much broader understanding of developmental histories and sociopolitical trajectories. It especially provides a perspective on the role of history in structuring social change and developing collective responses to societal reorganization often missing from studies relegated to time-spans of only a decade or less.
